unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Effects of Degrees of Freedom on the Chi-square Distribution
question_text:
Which of the statements are true?

I. A small chi-square value leads to rejecting the null hypothesis.
II. The chi-square distribution is nearly normal for very large degrees of freedom.
III. If a chi-square value leads to rejecting the null hypothesis with $20$ degrees of freedom it must also lead to rejecting the null hypothesis with $10$ degrees of freedom.
solution:
Statement I. This is false. A large chi-square value is far out on the right tail, corresponding to a small area and a small P-value, and leading to rejecting the null hypothesis.

Statement II. This is true.

Statement III. This is also true. Looking at the chi-square table, we see that higher degrees of freedom require higher chi-square values to make the right tail probability small.

For example, $20$ degrees of freedom requires a chi-square value of $31.410$ to produce a $p$ value of $0.05$ or less. Ten degrees of freedom only requires a chi-square value of $18.307$ to produce a $p$ value of $0.05$ or less. A chi-square value of $31.410$ would definitely be extreme enough to reject the null hypothesis.
